akn:section.akn:heading: Protected communications; prohibition of retaliatory personnel actions

akn:subsection.akn:heading: Restricting Communications With Members of Congress and Inspector General Prohibited.—
Inspector General Investigation of Allegations of Prohibited Personnel Actions.—
Inspector General Investigation of Underlying Allegations.—

akn:content.akn:p: (d) Upon receiving an allegation under subsection (c), the Inspector General receiving the allegation shall conduct a separate investigation of the information that the member making the allegation believes constitutes evidence of wrongdoing (as described in subparagraph (A), (B), or (C) of subsection (c)(2)) if there previously has not been such an investigation or if the Inspector General determines that the original investigation was biased or otherwise inadequate. In the case of an allegation received by the Inspector General of the Department of Defense, the Inspector General may delegate that responsibility to the Inspector General of the armed force concerned.

akn:subsection.akn:heading: Action in Case of Substantiated Violations.—
Correction of Records When Prohibited Action Taken.—

akn:content.akn:p: (h) Upon the completion of all administrative review under subsection (f), the member or former member of the armed forces (except for a member or former member of the Coast Guard when the Coast Guard is not operating as a service in the Navy) who made the allegation referred to in subsection (c)(1), if not satisfied with the disposition of the matter, may submit the matter to the Secretary of Defense. The Secretary shall make a decision to reverse or uphold the decision of the Secretary of the military department concerned in the matter within 90 days after receipt of such a submittal.

(i) The Secretary of Defense, and the Secretary of Homeland Security with respect to the Coast Guard when it is not operating as a service in the Navy, shall prescribe regulations to carry out this section.
